ai-ud5.1:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-ud5.1:1.3_0: Just then King Pasenadi of Kosala was up in his best stilt house with queen Mallikā
ai-ud5.1:1.4_0: Then King Pasenadi addressed Queen Mallikā,
ai-ud5.1:1.5_0: “Mallikā, is there any other loved ones?”
ai-ud5.1:2.1_0: “Great king, there is no other dear to me.
ai-ud5.1:2.2_0: But, great king, is no other loved ones?”
ai-ud5.1:2.3_0: “I too am, Mallikā, even better than myself.”
ai-ud5.1:3.1_0: Then King Pasenadi of Kosala came downstairs from the stilt longhouse, went to the Buddha.
ai-ud5.1:3.2_0: King Pasenadi reported their conversation to the Buddha, and said,
ai-ud5.1:4.1_0: So, sir, I said to Queen Mallikā,
ai-ud5.1:4.2_0: ‘Mallikā, is there any other loved ones for you?’
ai-ud5.1:4.3_0: When this was said, Queen Mallikā said to me:
ai-ud5.1:4.4_0: ‘Great king, there is no other thing for me to declare themselves.
ai-ud5.1:4.5_0: But, great king, is no other thing in another?’
ai-ud5.1:4.6_0: When I said this, I said to Queen Mallikā,
ai-ud5.1:4.7_0: ‘We too don’t even have any more dear things to us.’”
ai-ud5.1:5.1_0: Knowing the meaning of this, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
ai-ud5.1:6.2_0: one finds no-one dearer than oneself.
ai-ud5.1:6.4_0: That’s why I can’t find ultimate peace.”
ai-ud5.1:6.5_0: First the first part of the body.
